awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Role of Material Culture in Developing Social Integration
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

This project explores the role of material objects in supporting social networks. Archaeological ceramics are uniquely positioned to offer insight on ancient peoples, reflecting both intentional and unintentional aesthetic, technical, and social choices. Building on a long-standing anthropological focus on prestige goods and exchange networks, a distinctive style of ceramic will be investigated. Integrating archaeological, art historical, and compositional data on this little understood social valuable, analysis of the production of these vessels and their movement through the landscape will demonstrate how material objects play a crucial role in the development of social relationships. In addition to contributing to gaps in existing compositional databases and assisting in the evaluation of methods for the chemical characterization of archaeological ceramics, the project will also provide students with the opportunity to gain laboratory skills related to archaeological science. 

Emphasizing the material basis for social networks, this project evaluates hypotheses of open and restricted access to a technically complex ceramic decorative style. Was this style available to the general population or restricted to elite communities? Which potting communities had access to the technical artistry required to produce these vessels, and did every community produce them using the same technique? Who exchanged ceramics with whom? Answering these questions furthers understandings of how social networks are supported and maintained by economically and symbolically significant social valuables. This project will use bulk compositional data acquired using instrumental neutron activation analysis, surface compositional data acquired using portable x-ray fluorescence, microscopic analysis of surface treatment, and data on style and form to trace interaction between archaeological sites. Examining the production of and access to these socially significant objects will illuminate systems of pottery production on a regional scale and the ways in which human relationships are negotiated and constructed through material means on a broader level.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Usulutan pottery was made by ancient people living in El Salvador and Guatemala between the years 700 BCE and 400 CE. The pottery is decorated using a special process, resulting in a bichromatic pattern of orange and yellow. Vessels with this decoration are well known from elaborate burials, but also appear in feasting contexts. Despite the abundance of Usulutan pottery in the Southern Maya Region, there has never been a systematic study. This grant supported an investigation of Usulutan pottery from an archaeometric perspective, thinking about production, exchange, and access. The goal was to better understand the role of Usulutan in supporting social structures.

Compositional analyses of archaeological ceramics can provide valuable archaeometric data related to the production, decoration, and exchange of pottery. This project embraced a portable methodology based around sampling previously excavated archaeological ceramics in museum collections. Eleven museums in the United States and Guatemala supplied ceramics for both destructive and nondestructive materials analysis. Archaeological sites represented in the ceramic dataset include Chalchuapa, Cotzumalhuapa, Isla El Espiritu Santo, Kaminaljuyú, Marinalá, Salinas La Blanca, Sin Cabezas, Tiquisate, and unprovenanced. Compositional data on the paste of over two hundred Usulután vessels was acquired using both portable X-ray fluorescence (pXRF) and instrumental neutron activation analysis (INAA). A DinoLite digital microscope was used to examine and record the vessel paste.

The 217 ceramic samples were classified into compositional groups A-H based on multivariate statistics. These groups were then compared to reference data on clays and ceramics from the area to determine likely source locations. Group A is found exclusively at the large regional centers of Kaminaljuyu and Chalchuapa. This group includes more complex vessel shapes and designs than other groups. Group A shows similarities to clays from the highlands, suggesting production around Kaminaljuyu. Group B is found mostly at Kaminaljuyu, but also smaller sites in the piedmont and is likely from the highlands. Group C is found predominantly at Sin Cabezas, with a few sherds at other sites. It shows strong compositional similarities to references from this Escuintla. Group D is found at Chalchuapa, but also at large and medium sites in Guatemala. Group D is most similar to reference material from Western El Salvador. Group E includes only samples from Cotzumalhuapa, which were likely made there. Group F is a mixed group not dominated by any one site, perhaps suggesting it originates from further away. Group G is found at Cotzumalhuapa and Isla El Espiritu Santo, and shows similarities to Escuintla clays. Group H includes only ceramics from Marinala and was likely produced near the site in Escuintla.

The largest cities, Kaminaljuyu and Chalchuapa, reveal different patterns. At Chalchuapa, 84% of the Usulután was locally produced. Only 15 % of the Usulután at Chalchuapa was from non-local sources, with a small amount from the Group A source associated with Kaminaljuyu. This is a stark contrast to Kaminaljuyú, where roughly 58% of the Usulután is local. The rest of the Usulutan at Kaminaljuyu is from non-local sources, mostly from Chalchuapa. While local production is common at Kaminaljuyú, there is a significant quantity of imported pottery. It is notable that the relationship between these sites is not reciprocal – Kaminaljuyu imports much more Usulutan than Chalchuapa. Looking at medium-sized sites in the piedmont shows further diversity. Cotzumalhuapa has the most compositional groups at any one site. 48% of the Usulután at Cotzumalhuapa is local, produced using two clay sources. The non-local pottery at Cotzumalhuapa makes up 50.23% of the Usulután at the site, and links the site to Sin Cabezas, the Guatemalan highlands, and Western El Salvador. Marinalá and Sin Cabezas follow an alternative pattern. People at Marinalá received 77.77% of their Usulután from the local Group H, which exclusively supplied the people in this city. At Sin Cabezas, 84.37% of the pottery is from local Group C. A small quantity of highland pottery is found at each site, but not in the quantities as at Cotzumalhuapa. Sin Cabezas also has a small amount of pottery from Chalchuapa’s Group D. Turning our attention to the smaller sites of Salinas La Blanca and Isla El Espiritu Santo reveals that neither small sites was producing their own Usulután pottery.

The compositional data indicates that Usulutan was a multifaceted tool for social interaction. People most likely shared meals using these patterned vessels during a myriad of social events. Group A vessels are found only at large centers and show a higher level of technical complexity than other groups, suggesting that these vessels were restricted to social interactions between elites. In contrast, Group H vessels are found only at the minor site of Marinala, indicating production focused on social events for people living in the city. Overall, Usulután pottery was an important component of the interaction between city-states, providing an avenue for the reinforcing of social bonds.
